Graphical abstract Two-dimensional oxygen-terminated BiXenes are a new class of high-efficient electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) with low overpotentials. Advanced materials for active hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts are central to the area of renewable energy. Here we report for the first time the application of two-dimensional (2D) oxygen-terminated BiXenes as a new family of electrocatalysts for the HER in terms of the following electrochemical descriptors: Gibbs free energy of H adsorption (ΔG H), exchange current density and the required potential to achieve a 10 mA/cm2 current density (polarization curve). The results reveal that oxygen-terminated BiXenes have a high density of catalytically active sites, excellent electric conductivity, and maintain a high HER activity over a wide range of hydrogen coverages. Among these systems, Mo2CO2 are identified as exceptional HER catalyst in virtue of the comparable overpotential (107 mV) to that of Pt (58 mV). Most importantly, on the basis of a concept of “electron donation”, depositing single transition metals (TM) on the surface of oxygen-terminated BiXenes to form single atom catalysts (SACs) and strain engineering, both of which are demonstrated to efficiently weaken the H bonding strength, are promising routes to enhance the HER activity of oxygen-terminated BiXenes. Our work is the first report of oxygen-terminated BiXenes, offering cost-effective alternatives to traditional Pt-based catalysts for advancing sustainable hydrogen evolution. Keywords Oxygen-terminated BiXenes Single atom catalysts HER Boosting the hydrogen evolution 1 Introduction The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is a crucial step in electrochemical water splitting and demands an efficient, durable and cheap catalyst [1-3]. However, the practical utility of HER in hydrogen generation has encountered numerous obstacles, partly because of the urgent requirement of suitable alternatives to scarce and nondurable noble-metal electrocatalysts. For example, the use of platinum has raised issues linked to cost and stability in non-acidic media. For an energy-efficient HER, a catalyst mush be able to trigger proton reduction with minimal overpotential and have fast kinetics. Recently, certain non-precious metals have been reported to act as alternatives for the hydrogen evolution (e.g., copper), but these are susceptible to acid corrosion and are typically much inferior to Pt-based catalysts, exhibiting higher overpotentials and lower stability [3]. The intriguing structural and electronic properties of two-dimensional (2D) materials offer new platforms for developing HER catalysts [4-8]. To date, emerging 2D HER catalysts based on non-metallic nanomaterials, in particular utilizing earth-abundant elements (e.g., such as MoS2), have attracted great attention, but the obtained current densities are still orders of magnitude lower than these attained with classical metallic catalysts [9,10]. In addition, the catalytically active sites are usually confined to edges or defects (as for instance with MoS2), while the majority of the in-plane atoms are catalytically inert [11,12]. Therefore, electrocatalysts with good electric conductivity and high density of catalytically active sites are highly desired. In recent years, transition metal carbides/nitrides (known as MXenes) arose as promising material as their 2D inheritors could be prepared by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and hydrofluoric acid etching of MAX phases (where ‘M’ designates transition metal, ‘A’ represents group A elements, and ‘X’ is C and/or N.) [13-15]. In the light of the favorable electric conductivity and surface area, MXenes have been explored for their application in metal ion batteries [16,17], supercapacitors [15,18], fuel cells [19], and many more [20-22]. In terms of their stability in acidic electrolytes, MXenes are expected to be extremely stable because they do even survive the harsh synthesis conditions of hydrofluoric acids. In fact, the release of H2 can always be observed during the synthesis process of MXenes, that is why MXenes are anticipated to be promising HER catalysts [23-27]. Motivated by these studies, for the first time we investigated the HER activity of a new family of 2D BiXenes having 2H symmetry, in particular Ti2C, V2C, Nb2C, Mo2C and Ti3C2, which are more stable than the 1T symmetry of common MXenes. As shown in Fig. 1 a and b, for the 1T phase, two metal atomic layers stack in A–B packing mode, whereas in the 2H phase, one metal layer shifts, turning the packing into A–A mode. They originate from the binary carbides and have the same chemical composition of MXenes, therefore they are referred to as BiXenes [28]. The metallic character makes BiXenes potentially interesting as transparent conductors such as touch screens and cathode for metal-ion batteries [29,30]. Also, the high thermal conductivity may be potentially interesting for electronics to solve the heat elimination for industrial exploitation [28]. In any case, there are only a few exemplary features, since the versatile features of BiXenes offer a truly exciting platform for HER catalysts. Our results show that the Gibbs free energy of H adsorption (ΔG H) on some of these oxygen-terminated BiXenes (e.g., for Ti2CO2, Mo2CO2 and Ti3C2O2) is close to zero, which is comparable to or even lower than that of currently used HER catalysts (e.g., Pt). Remarkably, it is of great interest that the HER activity of oxygen-terminated BiXenes can be optimized through depositing single transition metal (TM) atoms on the surface to form single atom catalysts (SACs), which is ascribed to the increase of oxygen p-orbital occupancy. Besides, strain can cause positive modifications in the H bonding strength, leading to further improvement of the HER activity. These superior characteristics of BiXenes make them interesting platforms for exploring cost-effective and efficient HER catalysts. 2 Computational methods All first-principles calculations were performed by spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [31]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) [32] potential was used with a plane-wave cutoff energy of 500 eV, and the convergence tolerance for the residual force and energy on each atom during structure relaxation were set to 0.01 eV/Å and 10−5 eV, respectively. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional within generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed [33,34]. For geometry optimization, Brillouin-zone integration was performed using a Γ-centered 5 × 5 × 1 k-point mesh and a denser 9 × 9 × 1 mesh for electronic calculations within the Monkhorst–Pack scheme. The vacuum space in the z-direction was larger than 20 Å, which was tested to be sufficient to prevent interactions between periodical images. It is well established that the Gibbs free energies of hydrogen adsorption (G H) is a key descriptor for the HER activity of catalysts and is determined by [35-44] Δ G H = Δ E H + Δ E ZPE - - T Δ S H where ΔE H denotes H adsorption energy, which is calculated by ΔE H = E (*+H) − E (*) − ½ E H2, with E (*+H), E (*) and E H2 being the total energies of a 2 × 2 supercell with and without adsorbed atomic (H) or molecular (H2) hydrogen, respectively. ΔE ZPE and ΔS H are the differences in zero-point energy and entropy between the adsorbed H atom and ½ H2 in gas phase, respectively. Thus, ΔE ZPE can be calculated as Δ E Z P E = E Z P E n H - E Z P E n - 1 H - 1 2 E Z P E H 2 where E Z P E n H is the zero-point energy of the catalyst with n adsorped H atoms, while E Z P E H 2 is the zero-point energy of H2 in gas phase. ΔS H can be obtained by Δ S H ≅ - 1 2 S H 2 0 where S H 2 0 is the entropy of gaseous H2 under standard conditions. The contributions from the catalysts surface to ΔE ZPE and ΔS H should be small and, thus, were neglected. With respect to Ti2CO2, for example, the vibration frequency of adsorbed H atom at 1/8 coverage is 4857.6 cm−1, which turned out to be not sensitive to the H coverage. Therefore, for H adsorpion on Ti2CO2 we obtained ΔG H ≅ ΔE H + 0.37 eV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal structures and electronic properties of oxygen-terminated BiXenes Previous XPS and EDS analyses indicated that MXenes are usually terminated with surface O* groups [45]. In this work, pristine and the corresponding oxygen-terminated BiXenes (namely, Ti2CO2, V2CO2, Nb2CO2, Mo2CO2, and Ti3C2O2) were therefore considered to examine their potential as HER electrocatalysts. In Fig. S1 in the Supporting Information (SI), the structures of oxygen-terminated BiXenes are presented, where the most stable configurations of Ti2CO2 and Ti3C2O2 show that the oxygen atoms locate at fcc sites (hollow sites as shown in Fig. 1c) on both faces of the basal plane. In cases of V2CO2, Nb2CO2 and Mo2CO2, oxygen prefers sitting at hcp sites (C atom sites), which is in accordance with previous results [46]. It is worth pointing out that the defect characteristic is not taken into accout as we only consider the intrisic catalytic performance of oxygen-terminated BiXenes and compare the results with those of MXenes without any defects. To further examine the stability of the oxygen-terminated BiXenes, 4 × 4 supercells are adopted to perform ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations using the Nosé thermostat beginning at 500 K. It can be observed that the structures remain very well and there is no significant distortion of the geometric structure, indicative of the high thermodynamic stability of oxygen-terminated BiXenes (Fig. S2). As illustrated in Fig. 2 , oxygen-termination preserves the metallic properties of the BiXenes considered here, guaranteeing the excellent electrical conductivity of the catalysts. Besides, charge is substantially spread out around the carbon and outer oxygen atoms (Fig. S3), implying electron transfer from metal to carbon/oxygen atoms and thereby robust ionic bonds. Thus, oxygen atoms could act as active sites for H adsorption. In light of these two crucial principles, the excellent electric conductivity and high number of active sites, oxygen-terminated BiXenes are expected to be promising candidates for efficient HER catalysts. 3.2 HER activity As indicated in Fig. 3 , ΔG H shows a certain H coverage dependence, which is certainly due to the net charge transfer upon H adsorption. Regarding Ti2CO2 for instance, ΔG H is –0.13 eV for a H coverage of θ = 1/8 ML, and change to be 0.03 eV when the coverage increases to 1/4 ML. It is indicative that the interactions between H and oxygen atoms are weakened as the H coverage increases. As suggested by Parsons [47], the optimum ΔG H should be around zero for an efficient catalyst, according to which Ti2CO2 could be deemed as a nearly perfect HER catalyst. As the H coverage increases to 3/8 ML and 1/2 ML, ΔG H are 0.11 and 0.25 eV, respectively, which are still relatively small, indicating that Ti2CO2 should be highly active over a wide range of H coverages (1/8 ML ≤ θ ≤ 3/8 ML with Δ G H ≤ 0.20 e V ). In case of Mo2CO2, ΔG H = 0.05 eV at a H coverage of 3/8 ML, while ΔG H = 0.08 eV for Ti3C2O2 at θ = 1/4 ML. Therefore, three oxygen-terminated BiXenes, including Ti2CO2, Mo2CO2 and Ti3C2O2, hide good HER activity behind the low overpotential. However, for V2CO2 and Nb2CO2, much negative ΔG H indicates strong interactions between H and oxygen atoms, which is adverse to the H2 release and severely weakens the HER performance. As a consequence, pristine V2CO2 and Nb2CO2 might not be ideal catalysts for HER, as high overpotential could be expected. As will be discussed later, the high overpotential could be reduced by single metal atom deposition and/or strain engineering. In Fig. 4 a, the volcano curve is plotted to shed more light on the catalytic activity of oxygen-terminated BiXenes. According to Nørskov’s assumption, where a simple kinetic model is developed to understand the origin of the valcano, the theoretical exchange current density i 0 is obtained on the basis of averaged H adsorption free energies ( Δ G H a ). If Δ G H a ≤ 0 , the following expression for i 0 at pH = 0 is adopted i 0 = - e k 0 1 1 + e x p - Δ G H a / k B T If Δ G H a > 0 , i 0 is calculated by i 0 = - e k 0 1 1 + e x p Δ G H a / k B T where k 0 is the rate constant. As there are no experimental data available, k 0 is set to 1 [35,36]. The volcano curve indicates i 0 as a function of Δ G H a , then the HER activity can be evaluated by the positions of i 0 and Δ G H a relative to the volcano peak, where a position closer to the peak demonstrates a higher HER activity. Accordingly, the Δ G H a of bare BiXenes with a H coverage of θ = 1/2 ML (see Table S1) and oxygen-terminated BiXenes with a H coverage of θ = 1/2 ML are calculated to obtain the theoretical current density. For pristine BiXenes, these catalysts exhibit too negative Δ G H a values and thus low i 0, which is adverse to the release of H during the HER process. However, oxygen-termination can weaken the interactions between H and oxygen atoms, promoting hydrogen release and leading to a high exchange current density, which should be favorable for the HER activity. In cases of Ti2CO2, Mo2CO2 and Ti3C2O2 with low overpotentials, for example, i 0 locates very close to the peak of the volcano curve, further confirming their best catalytic activity for HER. In fact, in addition to the exchange current density, I–V curve (polarization curve) is widely adopted to quantitatively evaluate the HER catalytic activity in experiments [12]. It is worth noting that the exchange current density is the forward (and backward) rate when the total HER is equilibrium (here U = 0), while the current density I at the electrodes depends on the potential applied to the electrodes [10]. The lower the required potential is to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2, the better the HER activity [37]. Here, the current density i can be obtained by the turnover frequency (TOF) and active site density (d active–site) [37] i = 2 e d a c t i v e - s i t e × T O F where e = 1.6 × 10–19C is the elementary charge and the factor 2 is for the two H atoms in H2. d active–site can be obtained by the number of active sites–surface area ratio (d active–site = 1.3 × 1015, 1.4 × 1015 and 1.5 × 1015 for Ti2CO2, Mo2CO2 and Pt, respectively). The TOF is determined using an Arrhenius type equation [37] T O F = A e x p Δ G H / k T where A is related to Tafel slope and can be benchmarked to that of Pt. In Fig. 4b and S4, it can be observed that the glassy carbon substrate has negligible HER activity and is therefore expected not to influence the ΔG H for oxygen-terminated BiXenes. In addition, the required potential to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2 is as low as –107 and –236 mV for Mo2CO2 and Ti2CO2. In comparison to commonly used Pt (–58 mV) and 2D MoS2 (which is far from satisfactory) catalysts, it is conclusive that statisfied HER activity can be expected for Ti2CO2 and especially Mo2CO2. 3.3 Boosting the hydrogen evolution As discussed above, strong interactions between H and oxygen atoms could handicap the HER activity, thus, seeking efficient ways to efficiently weaken the H bonding strength is urgently needed. It is worth noting that adding particular metal atoms on the catalysts to form SACs has drawn wide attention because of the opportunities it offers to enhance the catalytic performance [6,48-52]. These SACs present extremely high atom efficiency and excellent stability as well as high catalytic activity for various electrochemical reactions [6,48-52]. In accordance to this principle, we investigated whether the relatively low HER activity of V2CO2 and Nb2CO2 could probably be improved by depositing certain metal atoms on the catalyst’s surface. As illustrated in Fig. 5 a, hybridization between O-2p and H-1s orbitals forms fully filled bonding (σ) states, while the filling of antibonding (σ*) states depends on the occupancy of the O-2p orbitals. According to the molecular orbital theory, occupancy of the antibonding σ* states is related to the H bonding strength. As the occupancy of O-2p orbital increases due to the extra charge transferred from adsorbed metal atoms, more electrons will be filled into the antibonding σ* states, therefore, diminishing the bonding between oxygen-terminated BiXenes and H atoms and increasing ΔG H. In order to check this way of tuning the bonding strength by single metal atoms, representative TM atoms (here Fe, Co, Ni) have been adsorbed and the corresponding ΔG H were calculated. As illustrated in Fig. 5b, TM atoms prefer to be adsorbed at hollow sites of V2CO2 to form TM/V2CO2 SACs (Fe/V2CO2, Co/V2CO2 and Ni/V2CO2). It should be noted that the isolated TM atoms may tend to aggregate into clusters in order to reduce the overall surface free energy [38]. To access the stability of as-designed SAC, we compute the binding energies (E b) of these TM atoms on V2CO2, the cohensive energy (E coh) of TM atoms in their metal crystals, and the energy difference (ΔE = E b − E coh) between them (see Table S2). The negative energy difference demonstrates that these TM atoms tend to remain atomically adsorbed on V2CO2 rather than forming bulk crystals, excluding the TM atoms agglomerating and catalytic activity attenuating problems. On the surface of TM/V2CO2, as shown in Fig. S5, four representative H adsorption sites are referred to as S0, S1, S2, and S3 under different TM coverages. Table 1 summarizes the ΔG H values for TM/V2CO2. The calculated ΔG H values reveal that TM atoms indeed can weaken the strength of the HO bonds and thereby improve the HER activity. In certain cases, ΔG H are comparable to or even smaller than that of Pt (1 1 1) (–0.09 eV) [53]. In addition, we found that the HER activity of TM/V2CO2 is strongly correlated with the TM coverage and H adsorption sites. As shown in Table 1, ΔG H with H at the same adsorption site always increases when increasing the TM coverage. In the case of Co/V2CO2 with H atom locating at site S2, Fig. 5c shows that ΔG H increases from –0.86 to 0.25 eV as the Co coverage ranges from 0 to 25%. As summarized in Table 1, the ΔG H values are also sensitive to the hydrogen adsorption site. Under the same TM coverage (11.1%), for example, ΔG H on Fe/V2CO2 are –0.25, –0.13 and 0.12 eV with H at sites S0, S1 and S2, respectively. The promoting effects of TM atoms on the HER activity can be revealed by the charge density difference as shown in Fig. S6. Apparent charge transfer from TM atoms to BiXenes further activing the basal plane can be observed. Besides, the amount of transferred charge decreases from Fe to Ni because of the electronegativity and atomic radius, which is in good agreement with the best catalytic performance of Fe/V2CO2. According to Bader charge analysis [54], about 0.847 e is transferred from surrounding V atoms to oxygen atoms of pristine V2CO2. As listed in Table 1, the charge transferred to oxygen atoms (Q) increases after deposition of TM atoms, leading to further filling of the oxygen σ* states and thus weakening the HO bond strength, illustrating the origin of the improved HER activity. In terms of tuning the bonding strength of H with the catalyst, strain engineering could also be an efficient way to optimize the HER performance since it can change the bonding strength between H and the catalyst. Controllable strain can easily be applied to 2D materials by bending of a flexible substrate, elongating the substrate, piezoelectric stretching, exploiting the thermal expansion mismatch and controlled wrinkling, and so on [55-59]. Fig. 5d shows the ΔG H values for H adsorption at site S2 of 11.1% ML TM/V2CO2 under a biaxial strain between –3% and 3%. At the first glance, ΔG H monotonously decreases with increasing strain. In particular, proper strain could even make ΔG H being close to zero (see Fig. 5d). In Fig. 5e and f, the partial density of states (PDOS) and crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) are shown to verify the strain induced increase of HO bonding strength. It can be seen from the PDOS that with increasing the strain the oxygen p states (and thus their corresponding σ* states) in TM/V2CO2 become less occupied, which is further confirmed by the COHP. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, by means of comprehensive DFT computations, we explored the catalytic activity of a series of oxygen-terminated BiXenes and their derived single atom catalysts toward efficient HER. Results show that these catalysts, especially Mo2CO2, fulfill the following important criteria for active HER electrocatalysis: (1) good electric conductivity, which enables their catalytically active sites to be easily accessible for electrons coming from the external circuit; (2) a large density of highly active electrocatalytic sites; (3) low ΔG H, high exchange current density and low required potential to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2, indicating that these catalysts could maintain good catalytic activity over a wide range of H coverages. Finally, depositing single transition metal atoms on the surface to form single atom catalysts and strain engineering are revealed to be promising routes to boost the hydrogen evolution. The success of Ti2CO2 and Mo2CO2 is helpful for further exploration of promising BiXenes, such as the same group elements (Zr and W). This work not only opens up a new avenue of hydrogen evolution for renewable energy supply, but also sets up an efficient procedure in screening effective HER catalytsts based on the mechanism understanding, which can arouse great attention of HER electrocatalysis in future. coredata.dc:description: Advanced materials for active hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts are central to the area of renewable energy. Here we report for the first time the application of two-dimensional (2D) oxygen-terminated BiXenes as a new family of electrocatalysts for the HER in terms of the following electrochemical descriptors: Gibbs free energy of H adsorption (ΔG H), exchange current density and the required potential to achieve a 10 mA/cm2 current density (polarization curve). The results reveal that oxygen-terminated BiXenes have a high density of catalytically active sites, excellent electric conductivity, and maintain a high HER activity over a wide range of hydrogen coverages. Among these systems, Mo2CO2 are identified as exceptional HER catalyst in virtue of the comparable overpotential (107 mV) to that of Pt (58 mV). Most importantly, on the basis of a concept of “electron donation”, depositing single transition metals (TM) on the surface of oxygen-terminated BiXenes to form single atom catalysts (SACs) and strain engineering, both of which are demonstrated to efficiently weaken the H bonding strength, are promising routes to enhance the HER activity of oxygen-terminated BiXenes. Our work is the first report of oxygen-terminated BiXenes, offering cost-effective alternatives to traditional Pt-based catalysts for advancing sustainable hydrogen evolution.
coredata.dc:title: Oxygen-terminated BiXenes and derived single atom catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction
